titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the George Dibell papers ARC.019
titlestmt.author: Nicholas Pavlik
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-08-21 11:19:16 +0000.

did.abstract: The George Dibell papers consist of two documents. The first is the last will and testament of Captain George Dibell, dated April 25, 1721, signed by Dibell and witnesses Samuel Smith, Samuel Smith, Jr., and Eponetus Platt. The second is a document dating from August 10, 1741, verifying that Eponetus Platt was a witness to Dibell's will, signed by Platt and Charles Sexton, Justice.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); George Dibell papers, ARC.019, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Captain George Dibell lived in Huntington, Long Island during the 18th century. Details regarding his life are unknown.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The George Dibell papers consist of two documents. The first is the last will and testament of Captain George Dibell, dated April 25, 1721, signed by Dibell and witnesses Samuel Smith, Samuel Smith, Jr., and Eponetus Platt. The second is a document dating from August 10, 1741, verifying that Eponetus Platt was a witness to Dibell's will, signed by Platt and Charles Sexton, Justice.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Minimally processed to the collection level.
The collection combines the accessions 1977.240 and 1977.244.
